docs.title: Welcome to the DevOps Docs Automation Project
docs.text: A comprehensive demonstration of modern documentation automation using MkDocs and GitHub Actions.

docs.title: 🚀 Project Overview
docs.text: This project showcases a complete automated documentation pipeline that integrates seamlessly into your DevOps workflow. Every time you push changes to the main branch, the documentation is automatically rebuilt and deployed to GitHub Pages—no manual intervention required.

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
• Always Up-to-Date: Documentation stays synchronized with your codebase
  • Zero Maintenance: Automated builds eliminate manual deployment tasks
  • Professional Presentation: Clean, searchable Material Design interface
  • CI/CD Integration: Demonstrates best practices for documentation in DevOps pipelines

docs.title: ✨ Key Features
docs.text:
• Automated Deployment: Push to main → Documentation automatically updates
  • Material Theme: Modern, responsive design with built-in search
  • Version Control: Full documentation history tracked in Git
  • Markdown-Based: Simple, developer-friendly authoring experience
  • GitHub Pages Hosting: Free, reliable, and fast content delivery

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Welcome to the DevOps Docs Automation project! This initiative demonstrates how modern DevOps practices can transform documentation from a tedious afterthought into an automated, integral part of your development workflow.

docs.title: 🎯 Project Goals
docs.text:
This project aims to:

  1. Demonstrate Automation: Show how documentation can be automatically built and deployed
  2. Showcase Best Practices: Illustrate industry-standard DevOps patterns for documentation
  3. Reduce Manual Work: Eliminate repetitive deployment tasks through automation
  4. Improve Consistency: Ensure documentation always reflects the current state of the project
  5. Educational Purpose: Provide a learning resource for COMP4964 students and developers

docs.title: The Documentation Pipeline
docs.text: Our automated documentation pipeline consists of three main components:

docs.title: 1. Source Content (Markdown)
docs.text:
• Documentation written in simple Markdown format
  • Stored in the /docs directory alongside code
  • Version-controlled with Git for full history tracking

docs.title: 2. Build System (MkDocs)
docs.text:
• Static site generator that transforms Markdown into HTML
  • Material theme provides modern, responsive design
  • Built-in search functionality for easy navigation
  • Configurable via mkdocs.yml file

docs.title: 3. Automation & Deployment (GitHub Actions)
docs.text:
• Triggered automatically on every push to the main branch
  • Installs dependencies and builds the documentation site
  • Deploys to GitHub Pages without manual intervention
  • Complete build logs for troubleshooting

docs.title: Workflow Diagram
docs.text:
Developer pushes code → GitHub detects change → GitHub Actions triggered
                                                          ↓
                                                  Sets up Python environment
                                                          ↓
                                                  Installs MkDocs + Material
                                                          ↓
                                                  Builds static site
                                                          ↓
                                                  Deploys to GitHub Pages
                                                          ↓
                                                  Documentation live!

docs.title: The Traditional Problem
docs.text:
Without automation, documentation workflows suffer from:

  • Staleness: Docs quickly become outdated as code evolves
  • Manual Deployment: Developers must remember to build and deploy
  • Inconsistency: Different team members may use different processes
  • Time Waste: Repetitive tasks that could be automated
  • Lower Priority: Manual effort means docs get neglected

docs.title: The Automated Solution
docs.text:
With our approach, you get:

  • ✅ Always Current: Docs automatically update with every code push
  • ✅ Zero Friction: No deployment steps to remember or execute
  • ✅ Standardized Process: Same workflow for everyone
  • ✅ Time Savings: Automation handles all the heavy lifting
  • ✅ Higher Quality: Less burden means better-maintained docs

docs.title: MkDocs
docs.text:
• What: Static site generator specifically designed for project documentation
  • Why: Simple, fast, and purpose-built for technical docs
  • Features: Built-in search, responsive themes, easy navigation
  • Language: Python-based, widely adopted in the developer community

docs.title: Material for MkDocs
docs.text:
• What: Modern, feature-rich theme for MkDocs
  • Why: Professional appearance with excellent UX
  • Features: Dark mode, customizable colors, social cards, tabs
  • Popularity: Industry standard for Python project documentation

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
• What: GitHub's integrated CI/CD automation platform
  • Why: Native integration with GitHub repositories
  • Features: Free for public repos, easy YAML configuration, extensive marketplace
  • Use Case: Automatic builds and deployments on code changes

docs.title: GitHub Pages
docs.text:
• What: Free static site hosting by GitHub
  • Why: Zero cost, automatic HTTPS, seamless GitHub integration
  • Features: Custom domains, automatic SSL, CDN-backed
  • Limitations: Static content only (perfect for documentation)

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
• Less Context Switching: Write docs alongside code
  • Version Control: Full history of documentation changes
  • Easy Reviews: Documentation changes go through pull requests
  • Preview Changes: See doc updates before they go live

docs.title: For Teams
docs.text:
• Onboarding: New members find up-to-date information
  • Collaboration: Everyone contributes using familiar tools (Git, Markdown)
  • Transparency: Build logs show exactly what happened
  • Reliability: Automated processes are more consistent than manual steps

docs.title: For Projects
docs.text:
• Professional Image: Quality docs signal a mature project
  • User Adoption: Good documentation increases usage
  • Reduced Support: Clear docs answer questions proactively
  • Maintainability: Future contributors understand the project faster

docs.title: Internal Tools

docs.title: Educational Resources

docs.title: 🎓 Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By exploring this project, you'll understand:

  1. CI/CD Principles: How automation improves development workflows
  2. Documentation as Code: Treating docs like any other code artifact
  3. GitHub Actions: Writing and debugging workflow files
  4. Static Site Generation: How tools like MkDocs work
  5. DevOps Culture: The value of automation and continuous delivery

docs.title: 🔄 The Continuous Documentation Cycle
docs.text:
Write/Update Docs → Commit to Git → Push to GitHub → Auto-Build → Auto-Deploy
                                                                        ↓
                    Feedback Loop ← Users Read Docs ← Live on GitHub Pages

This cycle ensures documentation is never a separate, disconnected task—it's a natural part of the development process.

docs.title: Setup Guide
docs.text: This comprehensive guide will walk you through setting up the project locally, configuring MkDocs, and understanding the automated deployment process.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.7+: Required for MkDocs
  • pip: Python package manager (usually comes with Python)
  • Git: For version control
  • Text Editor: VS Code, Sublime, or your preferred editor
  • GitHub Account: For deploying to GitHub Pages

docs.title: Verify Your Installation
docs.text:
Check if Python is installed:

python3 --version

Check if pip is available:

pip3 --version

Check if Git is installed:

git --version

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/PouyanNorouzi/COMP4964ProjectDemo.git
cd COMP4964ProjectDemo

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Install MkDocs and the Material theme:

pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

Or use a virtual environment (recommended):

# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv venv

# Activate it
source venv/bin/activate  # On Linux/Mac
# OR
venv\Scripts\activate  # On Windows

# Install dependencies
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

docs.title: 3. Serve Locally
docs.text:
Start the development server:

mkdocs serve

Open your browser and navigate to: http://127.0.0.1:8000

You should see the documentation site running locally with live reload enabled!

docs.title: 📝 Project Structure
docs.text:
Understanding the file organization:

COMP4964ProjectDemo/
│
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
│       └── docs.yml          # GitHub Actions workflow
│
├── docs/                      # Documentation source files
│   ├── index.md              # Homepage
│   ├── introduction.md       # Project introduction
│   ├── setup-guide.md        # This file
│   └── faq.md                # FAQ page
│
├── mkdocs.yml                # MkDocs configuration
└── README.md                 # GitHub README

docs.title: mkdocs.yml
docs.text:
The main configuration file for your documentation site:

site_name: DevOps Docs Automation Demo
theme:
  name: material

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Introduction: introduction.md
  - Setup Guide: setup-guide.md
  - FAQ: faq.md

docs.title: .github/workflows/docs.yml
docs.text:
The GitHub Actions workflow that automates deployment:

name: Deploy Docs

on:
  push:
    branches: ["main"]

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repo
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: "3.x"

      - name: Install MkDocs
        run: pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

      - name: Build site
        run: mkdocs build --clean

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./site

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Edit Markdown Files: Modify files in the /docs directory
  2. Live Preview: Changes appear instantly at http://127.0.0.1:8000
  3. Check Navigation: Ensure new pages are added to mkdocs.yml
  4. Test Links: Verify all internal links work correctly

docs.title: Common MkDocs Commands
docs.text:
# Start development server with live reload
mkdocs serve

# Start server on different port
mkdocs serve -a localhost:8080

# Build static site (output in ./site directory)
mkdocs build

# Build with clean slate (removes old files)
mkdocs build --clean

# Validate configuration
mkdocs build --strict

# Deploy to GitHub Pages manually (not needed with Actions)
mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: Adding New Pages
docs.text:
1. Create a new .md file in the /docs directory: bash touch docs/new-page.md

  2. Add content to the file: ```md # New Page Title

Your content here... ```

  1. Update mkdocs.yml navigation: ```yaml nav:

    • Home: index.md
    • Introduction: introduction.md
    • Setup Guide: setup-guide.md
    • New Page: new-page.md
    • FAQ: faq.md ```

  2. Save and the page appears immediately in local server!

docs.title: Basic Theme Configuration
docs.text:
Extend mkdocs.yml with theme options:

theme:
  name: material
  palette:
    primary: indigo
    accent: indigo
  font:
    text: Roboto
    code: Roboto Mono
  features:
    - navigation.tabs
    - navigation.sections
    - search.highlight

docs.title: Adding Features
docs.text:
Enable additional Material theme features:

theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - navigation.instant      # Instant loading
    - navigation.tracking     # URL updates with scroll
    - navigation.tabs         # Top-level tabs
    - navigation.sections     # Section navigation
    - navigation.expand       # Expand sections by default
    - navigation.top          # Back to top button
    - search.suggest          # Search suggestions
    - search.highlight        # Highlight search terms
    - content.code.copy       # Copy button for code blocks

docs.title: Custom Colors
docs.text:
theme:
  name: material
  palette:
    # Light mode
    - scheme: default
      primary: blue
      accent: light blue
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-7
        name: Switch to dark mode
    # Dark mode
    - scheme: slate
      primary: blue
      accent: light blue
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-4
        name: Switch to light mode

docs.title: Automated Deployment (GitHub Actions)
docs.text:
The project is already configured for automatic deployment! Here's what happens:

  1. Trigger: You push changes to the main branch
  2. GitHub Actions: Workflow is triggered automatically
  3. Build: MkDocs builds the static site
  4. Deploy: Site is published to gh-pages branch
  5. Live: Changes appear on GitHub Pages within minutes

docs.title: Enabling GitHub Pages (First Time)
docs.text:
If setting up a new repository:

  1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Click Settings → Pages
  3. Under "Source", select Deploy from a branch
  4. Select branch: gh-pages
  5. Select folder: / (root)
  6. Click Save

docs.title: Viewing Your Site
docs.text:
After deployment, your site will be available at:

https://pouyanorouzi.github.io/COMP4964ProjectDemo/

docs.title: Manual Deployment (Alternative)
docs.text:
If you prefer to deploy manually:

# Build and deploy in one command
mkdocs gh-deploy

# With custom commit message
mkdocs gh-deploy -m "Updated documentation"

docs.title: Build Fails in GitHub Actions
docs.text:
Check the Actions tab in your repository to see error logs.

Common issues:

  • Missing dependencies: Ensure mkdocs-material is installed in workflow
  • Invalid YAML: Validate mkdocs.yml syntax
  • Broken links: Fix any references to non-existent files
  • Permissions: Ensure Actions has write permissions (Settings → Actions → General)

docs.title: Local Server Won't Start
docs.text:
# Check if port 8000 is in use
lsof -i :8000

# Kill the process if needed
kill -9 <PID>

# Or use a different port
mkdocs serve -a localhost:8080

docs.title: Changes Not Appearing
docs.text:
• Clear browser cache: Hard refresh with Ctrl+Shift+R (or Cmd+Shift+R on Mac)
  • Rebuild: Stop server and run mkdocs build --clean then mkdocs serve
  • Check file save: Ensure your editor saved the file

docs.title: MkDocs Not Found
docs.text:
# Ensure MkDocs is installed
pip install --upgrade mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Or if using venv, activate it first
source venv/bin/activate
